loans.use: to buy land  for farming.

loans.name: Sedi

texts.en:
Sedi is 44 years old, married, and has two children: 16-year-old and 11-year-old daughters. His daughters go to school. He wants his daughters to become an engineer and a doctor. His wife stays at home, so he is the only one earning an income. 

Sedi is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from Fuzuli city. Now he lives in the Fuzuli region, which is close to the occupied border, with his wife and children. 

He started his business eight years ago, driving a taxi. Now Sedi needs a 1,500 AZN (Azerbaijani New Manat) loan to buy a new engine for the car. He wants to use the money from his expanded business to help his family. In the future, Sedi wants to buy a new car; this will be more profitable for his business. Sedi is thankful to Komak and Kiva for supporting him.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for the car.

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en: Vicent is a 33-year-old man with eleven children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. He has been growing cocoa for the past ten years and with the proceeds he has been able to buy a motorcycle for his transport business and to educate his children. Like most farmers he faces the challenges of price fluctuations and unpredictable weather changes which reduce his outputs. Vicent intends to use the loan facility to buy more cocoa from other farmers and sell it at a higher price.

loans.use: to buy cocoa to sell.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia is a married woman staying together with her husband and two children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past two years, she has operated a charcoal selling business. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business to be a wholesale supplier of charcoal in the village. 

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Ana

texts.es: Ana tiene 39 años de edad, es una mujer que salio adelante sola, gracias a su fortaleza, vive en casa propia a lado de su madre y su hijo.Ana se dedica a la venta de pollos siendo su hogar su propio centro de trabajo, se inicio en esta actividad buscando un trabajo estable para así incrementar sus ingresos y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. al inicio se le complicaron las cosas por que no contaba con la solvencia económica para iniciar un negocio, pero gracias al apoyo de toda su familia pudo salir adelante y tener ahora un negocio estable.Ahora espera surgir y seguir creciendo como lo ha hecho hasta ahora para  aumentar sus ingresos económicos .Este es su primer crédito con Kiva, por lo que agradece el apoyo económico recibido y se compromete a ser responsable y puntual con el pago de sus cuotas.Con el monto solicitado de S/.500 soles comprará pollo al por mayor para aumentar su negocio y dinamizar sus ventas.
texts.en: Ana is 39 years old. She is a woman who got ahead by herself, thanks to her strength. She lives at home with her mother and her son. Ana sells chickens and her home is her workplace. She started this activity by seeking stable work so she could increase her income and improve her family's quality of life. At first, things were complicated for her because she wasn't financially solvent, but thanks to her whole family's help, she was able to get ahead and now has a stable business. Now she hopes to go forward and keep growing like she has so far, in order to increase her income. This is her first loan with Kiva, and she is grateful for the financial support she has received. She is committed to being responsible and make her payments on time. With the amount of  S/.500 soles that she has asked for, she will buy chicken wholesale to grow her business and invigorate her sales.

loans.use: to buy chickens wholesale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret  is a single mother of three children, and two of her children go to school. She has a business of selling soft drinks and has been in this business for four years. 

She has applied for a loan of 500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more crates of soda, mineral water, passion fruits, sugar and oranges   for making fresh juice.  She works in the market six days out of every week and sells on a retail basis only. Her major business challenges include seasonality and transportation.  

She is aspiring of owning a big deep freezer for cooling juice and also to build her own house. She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity but not piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soda, mineral water, passion fruits, sugar and oranges for making fresh juice.

loans.name: Eter

texts.en:
Eter is 59 years old. She lives alone in Vardisubani village, Lagodekhi district. 

Eter has requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and poor living conditions.
 
Eter has a plot of agricultural land, where cucumbers and eggplants are grown. Harvested products are sold locally at the markets and she gets a small monthly income. 

Eter requested a loan from Credo to start a family business. Eter has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions for rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With her credit Eter will purchase all the needed equipment to open a Georgian bread bakery. She owns a commercial space which will be used as a bakery. After purchasing a dough mixer and flour, she will start baking the bread herself and sell it from the bakery. Her shop is in the populous area so the business will be successful and will significantly increase her income. With the increased income Eter wants to renovate her house in order to have better living conditions.

loans.use: To open a Georgian bread bakery.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is married with four children, and all her children go to school. She also takes care one of her brother's children. She has a business of selling used clothes and has been in this business for six years. 

She has applied for a loan of 500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bales of used clothes. She moves door-to-door, selling used clothes. She works six days out of every week and sells on a retail basis only.  Her major business challenges include seasonality and the ever increasing prices of used clothes in Uganda.  

She is aspiring of getting a permanent business place and also to build her own house. She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity but not piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees, feeding the family and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase clothing for resale.

loans.name: Escalera Al Cielo Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ESCALERA AL CIELO” iniciará el segundo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de German Busch, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Eugenia es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de pescado, venta de comida, venta de verduras, tejido de mantas, venta de refrescos y gelatinas, venta de fruta.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Eugenia es integrante, ella indica que hace diez años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de su amiga que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de comida; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió cuando fue ayudante de cocina y posteriormente decide emprender su propio negocio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de pollos por mayor) que adquirirá de las tiendas distribuidoras de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a al elaboración lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es casada y tiene cuatro hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de salud y las capacitaciones.
texts.en:
The Escalera al Cielo (Ladder to Heaven) Communal Bank will begin its second loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the German Busch regional office. The group is made up of eight members led by a Board of Directors. The president is Sra. Eugenia. The members have a variety of businesses: selling fish, selling food, selling vegetables, weaving shawls, selling soft drinks and jello, and selling fruit.

The loan they are seeking will help them and Sra. Eugenia with their small businesses. She joined Pro Mujer ten years ago at the invitation of a friend who was a member of the institution. Nowadays Eugenia has a business selling meals. She learned how to make food when she was a cook’s assistant and then later she decided to start her own business.

Her share of the loan money will be used to buy chickens at wholesale prices from the distributors in the town of El Alto. After preparing them she will sell them on her stall. The business provides her with an income to help as much as possible with household expenses as she is married and has four children.

Eugenia says that the aspects of Pro Mujer she likes most are the talks about health and the training.

loans.use: buy chickens wholesale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 49 years old and lives at Paynesville North, which has the largest local market in Montsorrade. She’s married and her husband is not working. They have six children between 15 and 29 years old. Three are in school and live at home. She describes herself as a hardworking person.

For the past 20 years she has been involved with business. Currently, she sells onions, peppers, vita, salt, etc., at the local market. She started this present business with 1,000 LRD given to her by her mother. She gets her goods to her table at the market by means of shared taxi. She likes her business because of the ways customers respond to it.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more onions, peppers, vita, salt, etc., for her business. She plans to buy a piece of land and build a house. She likes to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia to enable small business people to increase their business volume.

loans.use: to purchase more onion, pepper, vita, salt, etc., for her business.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is a 29-year-old single  mother of two children living in Masindi, Uganda. She practices farming and earns a salary, as well as selling second-hand clothes as her additional income source. With the proceeds, she has been able to pay school fees for her sisters and buy land. Her personal goal is to upgrade her studies, while her business goal is to become a model farmer. 

Annet intends to use the loan to buy seedlings for planting, as the season is fast approaching.

loans.use: to buy seedlings for planting, as the season is fast approaching.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha operates a fresh juice  business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby.  She is requesting another loan from Yehu, which she joined to access loans to boost her business, for 40,000 KES, which she will use to purchase fresh fruits, mangoes, oranges, pawpaws, and watermelons.

Asha faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.She dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fresh fruits, mangoes, oranges, pawpaws, and watermelons.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es: Rosario tiene 51 años de edad es casada y vive junto a su esposo en su casa propia.Su principal actividad es el comercio, hace un año que Rosario decidió dedicarse a la venta de bebidas gasificadas y golosinas, buscando mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. Fue gracias a sus Padres que Rosario decide iniciarse en esta actividad ya que ellos tienen su propio negocio y con el apoyo que le brindaron y el esfuerzo de Rosario pudo salir adelante. Antes de tener su propio negocio el problema más común era la falta de dinero pero gracias a su lucha constante pudo salir adelante.Lo que ahora espera es mejorar la infraestructura de su negocio ya que desea tener un ambiente apropiado para realizar todas sus ventas.Este es su primer crédito con Kiva, por lo que agradece el apoyo financiero recibido, el cual le ayudara a mejorar sus ingresos económicos.Rosario, invertirá los S/. 1500 soles en la compra de bebidas gasificadas y golosinas para implementar su tienda.
texts.en:
51-year old Rosario is married and lives with her husband in their own house. Her main job is running a business selling soft drinks and candy, a business she started a year ago when she was looking for a way to improve her family’s standard of living. With help from her parents who had their own business and her own hard work, Rosario was able to make progress.

Before having her own business, the most common problem was a lack of money but thanks to her constant efforts, she was able to get ahead. Now Rosario wants to improve her store so she has an appropriate place in which to sell her stock.

This is her first loan with Kiva, and she is grateful for the financial assistance that will help improve her income. Rosario will use the S/. 1500 soles to buy soft drinks and candy for her store.

loans.use: buy soft drinks and candy

loans.name: Lamula's Group

texts.en:
Lamula's group is comprised of four hardworking women. Lamula is 18 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past two years, Lamula has been working hard to manage her hairdressing salon.

To help expand her business, Lamula has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more hair extensions and a dryer for the salon. It will help Lamula to generate greater profits and pay for her child's school fees. Lamula hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build a house of her own.

Lamula is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more hair extensions and a dryer for the salon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy agricultural supplies

loans.name: Maria Gloria

texts.es:
María es madre soltera tiene 30 años de edad tiene una hija de 4 años de edad, vive en casa de la hermana junto a su hija en la ciudad de Guaranda Provincia de Bolívar.

Es integrante de la Ventanilla  Los pinos, se encuentra formada por 14 socios que son de la misma comunidad, se dedican a la agricultura queda a 40 minutos de la oficina Comunidad Pangua.

María se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de papas y crianza de pollos, ganado. Solicita el crédito para comprar un ganado y vacunas. Con la ayuda del crédito podrá aumentar los animales.  La compra lo realizará en la ciudad de Guaranda.  Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta son las enfermedades de los animales.

El sueño es tener un buen futuro y mejorar la economía. En el tiempo libre le gusta pasar descansando en la casa junto al hijo y pasear.
texts.en:
María, 30, is a single mother of a four-year-old girl. She lives at her sister’s together with her daughter in the city of Guaranda, Bolívar province.

María is a member of the communal bank Los Pinos, composed of fourteen members, all from the same community, which is located 40 minutes away from the office of the Community of Pangua.

María works in agriculture. She grows potatoes and raises chickens and cattle. She is requesting a loan to buy cattle and vaccines. With the help of this loan she will be able to have more animals, buying them in the city of Guaranda. Her main challenge is the animals’ diseases.

María’s dream is to have a good future and improve her financial situation. During her free time, she likes to rest at home with her daughter and go out for a walk.

loans.use: to buy cattle and vaccines.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en: Mwanamisi always struggles to improve her food stall, trying to sell more and save money in order to have a more formal establishment. She is applying for a loan to buy more beans, sugar, oil, vegetables, beef, chicken, and food packaging. She thanks all of you for the help provided.

loans.use: to buy more beans, sugar, oil, vegetables, beef, chicken, and food packaging to sell at her food stall.

loans.name: Artur

texts.en: Artur is from the town of Kapan, where he lives with his wife and two little children. Artur works at local company and is also engaged in agriculture. His livestock holding is small and currently includes five cows. Realizing that agricultural income is very important for him, Artur would like to expand his farming business. He has requested a loan from SEF International to purchase four oxen. This will increase his livestock, which will give him an opportunity to earn more income. He plans to work hard to have a big farm.

loans.use: to pay for four oxen.

loans.name: Sukoluhle

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 36-year-old Sukoluhle from Bulawayo. She is married with three children, two who attend school. Sukoluhle runs a manufacturing business producing bedspread covers, seat covers, curtains and children's dresses. The business has been in operation for four years. Sukoluhle says the main challenges she faces are accessibility to funding and a stable market to sell her goods. Sukoluhle has requested a loan of $500 to order more raw materials. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to increase her business capacity and will also enable her to pay for other household expenses. In the future Sukoluhle plans to own a clothing shop.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for use in her sewing business

loans.name: Ritah's Group

texts.en: Ritah's Group is comprised of two hard-working women. Ritah is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kalisizo in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past two years, Ritah has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fresh juice. To help expand her business, Ritah has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX (Ugandan Shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy passion fruit to make juice to sell, and it will help Ritah to generate greater profits and take good care of herself and her parents. Ritah hopes that in the future she will be able to own a big supermarket in town. Ritah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy passion fruit to make juice to sell.

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina  lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with four children, all of whom attend school. She is not looking after any additional family members.

She has been selling charcoal and banana leaves in the market for 10 years, working seven days a week. She does not have an additional source of income. 

Zaina has requested a loan of UShs 200,000 from MCDT- SACCO to enable her to buy more bags of charcoal for sale. Her challenges include seasonality and transportation. Her dream is to open a second outlet. She joined MCDT because, unlike other financial institutions in her area of residence, she did not need collateral to access loans. She rents a house with access to both electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Sarah is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kalisizo in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is single and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past two years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her salon where she does hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more hair extensions and a dryer for the salon, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and buy more hair cosmetics and hair braids. Sarah hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a bigger salon. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more hair extensions and a dryer for the salon

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia, 29, is a hardworking married lady and the mother of two. She is a livestock farmer and has been in the business for the last two years making a monthly income of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

She learnt about KADET Ltd. from other farmers in the area who are already registered and are being funded by KADET Ltd. She has acquired her first loan of 50,000 KES which will facilitate her purchase of animal feeds.

Sylvia plans to use the proceeds to increase her livestock as well as pay school fees for her children. Her dream is to see her children reach high levels of learning.

loans.use: to buy animal feeds

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en: Ronald is 45 years old, married, and the father of one child. For the past twenty-four years, he has earned a living by selling goods at his general store in Malindi. He earns a monthly profit of KES 21,000. Ronald was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer, and he is applying for his fifth loan, of KES 70,000, to buy additional stock for his general store, including cooking oil, washing powder, soft drinks and flour, to sell to his customers. He will use the profits made possible by this loan to pay school fees for his child and to expand his business. His goal for the future is to continue growing the business with a view to  providing his family with a stable financial status.

loans.use: to buy additional stock, including cooking oil, washing powder, soft drinks and flour, for his general store.

loans.name: Margret's Group

texts.en: Margret's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Margret is 19 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Margret has been working hard to manage her business selling popcorn snacks. To help expand her business, Margret has applied for a loan of 700,000 UGX (Ugandan Shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more popcorn maize and another machine for making popcorn, and it will help Margret to generate greater profits and to cover the basic needs of her family. Margret hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. Margret is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more popcorn maize and another machine for making popcorn.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is still in business as a farmer. She has been able to improve her farming with the financial support she has received from KADET LTD. She bought seedlings and fertilizers with her previous loan, and she got a bumper harvest. After selling the produce from her farm, she paid school fees for the children. She is now applying for her third loan, which she intends to use to prepare her land for this planting season.

loans.use: to prepare her land for this planting season.

loans.name: Lovincer's Group

texts.en:
Lovincer's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Lovincer is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kalisizo in the Masaka region of Uganda. For the past two years, Lovincer has been working hard to manage her fresh food business. 

To help expand her business, Lovincer has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more raw fresh food such as raw bananas to sell, and will help Lovincer to generate greater profits and take care of her young sisters and her mother. Lovincer hopes that in the future she will be able to own a retail shop. 

Lovincer is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more raw fresh food such as raw bananas to sell

loans.name: Pilate

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 33-year-old Pilate from Bulawayo. He is married with one child. He also cares for two dependents. Pilate runs a retail business selling clothes, shoes, ladies' wear and phones as well. The business has been in operation for four years. He says the main challenge faced is lack of capital to expand operations. 

Pilate has requested a loan of $500 to buy more stock of clothes, footwear and kids' wear, as well as cellphones. He says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow him to cover household expenses and other business expenses. In the future Pilate plans to increase business capacity  by opening a shop in town.

loans.use: to replenish and change stock in preparation for the coming cold season

loans.name: Aunty

texts.en: Although she has received no formal education, Aunty is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling earrings and other women’s accessories in Abrishia (near Cape Coast). She has been involved in this enterprise for a number of years. Aunty is married and has one child. Her husband works as a teacher. The proceeds from her business normally go toward helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their child’s school fees. Aunty wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, allowing her to sell greater quantities of accessories. In the long term, Aunty plans to reinvest future profits into her business, helping the business expand so she can meet the rising demands of customers.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels.

loans.name: Tusigaigoa

texts.en: Tusigaigoa is 42 years old and married with 2 children. She owns and operates a small store, selling a variety of general items. She has been doing this for 4 years. Tusigaigoa needs a loan to buy tins of tuna fish, chop suey noodles, box of noodles, sack of sugar, bag of rice, sack of flour, cooking oil, snacks, laundry soap and soft drinks. She hopes to use her profits to pay for her children's education. She became a member of SPBD to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy tins of tuna fish, chop suey noodles, box of noodles, sack of sugar, bag of rice, sack of flour, cooking oil, snacks, laundry soap and soft drinks

loans.name: Vladislav

texts.en:
Vladislav lives in small town called Kajaran with his wife and son. He has been working at a local factory for many years and is also involved in agriculture. His herd of livestock is very small and includes only two cows and two bulls. As his salary is hardly enough for covering his family's basic needs, agriculture helps Vladislav to have a stable income. Realizing that profit from his agricultural business is very important for him, Vladislav would like to expand it. 

He has requested a loan from SEF International in order to increase his farming business. With the loan's help he plans to purchase three cows. The loan is very important for Vladislav to be able to gather more income and ensure better living conditions for his family.

loans.use: to pay for three cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of charcoal.

loans.name: Lyudmila

texts.en:
Lyudmila is from the Shamb community of the Syunik region. She lives with her son and works hard to give him appropriate living conditions. 
Lyudmila has been running her farm for many years. She keeps livestock (2 cows, 18 sheep), cultivates barley and potato, and grows different kinds of trees (peach, apricot, cherry, nut, apple, and pear trees). 
As agriculture is the only source of income for Lyudmila, it is very important for her to gather a good harvest. She sells that harvest locally and earns income which is vital for her to make ends meet. Lyudmila would like to expand her farm but she has no means to finance an expansion, so she has decided to apply for this loan. With the loan's help she will purchase six calves and fertilizer, which is very important for successful land cultivation. The loan will help Lyudmila to cover fuel costs so she can take the harvest to the market.
Lyudmila dreams of having a big farm and will do her best to make her dream come true.

loans.use: to pay for six calves and to cover fuel costs and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more towels and cosmetics so she can improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Although he grew up with difficult circumstances, Daniel is an entrepreneur. He specializes in clothing sales in Abrishia (near Cape Coast). He has been involved in this enterprise for a number of years. Daniel is single without any children. The proceeds from his business normally go towards supporting Daniel himself and his extended family. Daniel wants to use his loan to increase his current inventory levels, allowing him to sell greater quantities of clothing. In the long term, Daniel plans to reinvest future profits into his business, helping him expand and meet the increasing demands of customers.

loans.use: to increase his current inventory levels.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for community health work and taxi business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motocycle for community health work and taxi business

loans.name: Sabrina

texts.en: Even though Sabrina grew up in poverty without an education, this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Currently, Sabrina is an entrepreneur. She sells chips in Abrishia (near Cape Coast). Her business has grown substantially since she began a number of years ago. She uses the income from her business to help her husband raise their three children. Sabrina has identified growing demands from her customers for her product. Nevertheless, she is unable to meet their needs due to limited inventory capacity. She plans to use her loan to purchase more ingredients to make more chips to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Sabrina wants to ensure that all her children will be given the opportunity to live outside of poverty.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to make more chips to sell.

loans.name: Abenawa

texts.en: Although she has received no formal education, Abenawa is an entrepreneur. She prepares and sells Banku, a traditional Ghanaian dish made using fermented corn/cassava dough that is mixed proportionally and cooked in hot water into a smooth, whitish, consistent paste. Abenawa can be found selling Banku in Abrishia  (near Cape Coast). She has been involved in this enterprise for a number of years. Abenawa is married and has three children. Her husband works as a farmer. The proceeds from her Banku business normally go toward helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. Abenawa will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of maize and cassava, which she hopes will improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Abenawa plans to diversify the type of products that she sells and adapt to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of maize and cassava to improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Edilma Del Rosario

texts.es: Edilma de 55 años de edad n habita en Soledad; ella es  casada y madre de  4 hijos en las edades de 16 a 29 años, quienes son el motor de su vida.  Desde hace  5 años Edilma  tiene un negocio de venta de productos, que promociona mediante guías  especializadas, como vestidos para damas calzado y perfumería. Inicialmente vendió chicha y otros refrescos, elaborados con frutas naturales. Así fue adquiriendo una clientela a la que poco a poco, fue conquistando para ofrecerle mercancías variadas y responderle de acuerdo a sus necesidades. Sus clientes la ubican en un local que surtió de productos en su propia casa y también vende artículos que le solicitan  sus clientes, y que  ella muestra con descuentos especiales a través de los  catálogos de su oferta. Sus ventas las realiza a crédito principalmente y de contado, trabajando de lunes a domingos, desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche. Sus principales clientes están ubicados en su vecindad  y en los alrededores del sector. Edilma ha crecido poco a poco, primero en clientela y luego en infraestructura, ella  cuenta con  vitrinas y un enfriador  como parte de los activos fijos mas importantes de su negocio.  En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará ropa para damas y caballeros, calzado infantil y perfumería, para responder a los pedidos que ha tomado en su preventa. Su mayor desafío es lograr que sus hijos sean profesionales,  para potencializar el éxito en su vida, para ellos trabaja permanentemente,  con el fin de lograr ese su sueño de prosperidad.
texts.en:
Edilma, age 55, lives in Soledad. She is a married mother of four children ages 16 to 29. They are what drive her in life. Edilma has had a business for five years selling products that she promotes via specialized guides. She sells, for example, dresses, shoes, and perfume. In the beginning she also sold chicha [a maize drink] and other drinks made from fruit. This is how she built up a customer base, and she started selling varied merchandise in response to their needs. She has a small store in her own home and stocks it with products, often ones that her clients request. She offers special discounts through her sales catalogues. 
She mainly sells on credit but also accepts cash. She works every day of the week from 8:00 am to 9:00 pm. Her main clients are located in her neighbourhood and the surrounding area. Edilma's business has grown bit by bit, first in clientele and then in infrastructure. Her most important assets are her display cases and cooler. She is applying for a loan on Kiva, her first loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, with which she will buy clothing for men and women, children's shoes, and perfume. This will allow her to respond to pending orders. 
She is working very hard to see her children become professionals, to succeed in life, and to have permanent jobs - a dream of prosperity.

loans.use: to buy clothing for men and women, children's shoes, and perfume.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances, Grace did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Grace sells doughnuts and chips in Abrishia (near Cape Coast). She has been in this business for a number of years. As a single mother with three children, Grace uses all of her income to feed and provide for her family. Grace will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of ingredients to make more doughnuts and chips, which she hopes will improve her overall sales. Grace wants to use the expected profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to make more doughnuts and chips

loans.name: Matagi

texts.en:
Matagi is 36 years old and married with three children. For the past four years, she has run a taxi business. Matagi transports people in her community. She joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital.

Matagi is requesting a loan to buy tires and paint her vehicle. She will use the profit from her loan to buy another taxi.

loans.use: to buy tires and paint her vehicle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for community health work and taxi business

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia opened a general store in 2009 with her own money and she generates a good income. She lives in a town with her family.

Lucia is requesting a 600 USD loan to buy stocks such as oil, slippers, detergent, and soap to sell. In the future, she is thinking of expanding her business since she has so much experience.

loans.use: to buy oil, slippers, detergent, and soap to sell

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa is 27 years old and married with five children. For the past two years, she has made and sold two-piece dresses for ladies, shirts for men, and children's dresses. Luisa joined SPBD in 2013 to gain access to financial services.

Luisa is requesting a loan to buy material, threads, and rubber bands. She plans to use the profit from her loan to pay for her family's household expenses.

loans.use: to buy material, threads, and rubber bands

loans.name: Pascuela

texts.en:
Pascuela runs a general store that helps generate income for her family. She opened her store a year ago with her own working capital of 250 USD.

Pascuela is requesting an 800 USD loan to keep her store stocked with items such as slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks (Coca-Cola, Sprite, Sagiko, and Fanta), and biscuits. She is a hardworking woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks, and biscuits

loans.name: Toetu

texts.en:
Toetu is 34 years old and married with two children. For the past three years, she has runs a small business selling pancakes in her community. Toetu joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital.

Toetu is requesting a loan to buy sacks of flour, cooking oil, baking powder, plastic bags, and a frying pan. With her earnings, she will help improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy sacks of flour, cooking oil, baking powder, plastic bags, and a frying pan

loans.name: Diego

texts.en:
Diego, a native of Peru, arrived in the United States ten years ago. Starting very young, Diego worked as a car salesman in his native country. However, once he arrived in the US, he  worked in different jobs until he was able to work in his area of expertise. 

While working at a car dealer, Diego acquired in-depth knowledge of how the car business operates in the U.S. To start his dream business, Diego obtained permits and licenses, leased a store locale, and passed inspections as a car dealer, a long, difficult and sometimes tedious task. The business began operating in December, 2012. Diego located the business in a Hispanic neighborhood to be able to service and target the Latino community with accessible prices and financing.  

Diego is requesting a loan to finance the purchase of more cars, in order to offer his clients more variety and more deals through expanded inventory.

Diego is married and the family has three children.

loans.use: to finance the purchase of more inventory, allowing him to offer his customers a wider variety of car brands and prices.

loans.name: Flaviana

texts.en: A $600 loan is being offered to Flaviana to improve her business. She has a kiosk where many people come to buy every day. She will buy some additional supplies such as biscuits, noodles, sugar, coffee and other items. She has been involved in business activities since 2011. She feels very comfortable running her business because she can earn money every day.

loans.use: to buy biscuits, noodles, sugar, coffee and other items

loans.name: Faifua

texts.en:
Faifua is a 42-year-old married woman with five children. She has a small plantation and grows taro and bananas to earn a living. She has been doing this for four years. 

Faifua has requested a loan to buy a backpack sprayer, chemicals, fertilizer and tree planter spades. She has been a member of SPBD since 2009. With her profits, Faifua hopes to renew her house.

loans.use: to buy a backpack sprayer, chemicals, fertilizer and a tree planter spade

loans.name: Cristian Hugo

texts.es:
Cristian tiene 19 años de edad es soltero no tiene hijos, vive en casa de unos tíos en la ciudad de Guaranda Provincia de Bolívar.

Es integrante de la Ventanilla  Los pinos, se encuentra formada por 14 socios que son de la misma comunidad, se dedican a la agricultura queda a 40 minutos de la oficina Comunidad Pangua.
Cristian se dedica a la siembra de todo tipo de grano y venta del grano además se dedica a la crianza de ganado, cerdos.

 Solicita el crédito para comprar fertilizantes, herbicidas, urea, semillas. Con la ayuda del crédito podrá comprar lo necesario para la agricultura.
Las compras  y las ventas las realizará en la ciudad de Guaranda y las ventas las realiza dentro y fuera de la provincia Bolívar.
El sueño es mejorar el negocio superarse en la vida y tener una vida segura. Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es la economía y la competencia.
En el tiempo libre le gusta disfrutar de las fiestas del carnaval.
texts.en:
Cristian is 19 years of age, is unmarried and does not have children. He lives with his aunt and uncle in the city of Guaranda in the province of Bolívar. 

He is a member of the solidarity group "Los Pinos" which is comprised of 14 members from the same community. They work in agriculture and are located 40 minutes from the office "Comunidad Pangua". Cristian works planting all types of grains. He also sells grains and raises cattle and pigs.  

He is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers, herbicides, urea, and seeds. With the help of the loan he will be able to buy the agricultural supplies he needs. He does his buying and selling in the city of Guaranda. He also sells outside of the province of Bolívar. 

His dream is to improve the business, to improve himself and to have a stable life.  The challenges that he faces include the economy and competition. In his free time he likes to enjoy carnival celebrations.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, herbicides, urea, and seeds.

loans.name: Esperanca Group

texts.en: Paskalya is one of the members of the Esperanca Group (Esperanca means hope).  She is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy some additional supplies such as fuel (diesel and petrol), seasonings, vegetables, shampoo, coffee, etc. She is a hard working woman who started her business a year ago with her own working capital of $70.00.

loans.use: to purchase fuel, seasonings, vegetables, shampoo, coffee, etc.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is a 49-year-old married woman with four children. She makes and sells clothes in her community to earn a living. She has four years of experience with this business. 

Rita needs a loan to buy a sewing table and needles and to pay for her kids' school fees. She plans to use her profits to expand her business in the future. Rita has been a member of SPBD since 2010.

loans.use: to buy a sewing table and needles and to pay for her kids' school fees

loans.name: Emmadelyn

texts.en:
Emmadelyn  is 32 years old and married with four children. She is a resident of Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. For the past three years, Emmadelyn has run a retail store where she sells a variety of food products in her local community. She earns about 3,000 PHP in monthly income from her store. Emmadelyn joined GDMPC in 2008 to gain access to financial services.

Emmadelyn  is requesting a 4,000 PHP loan from GDMPC to purchase additional stocks such as sugar, dried fish, and canned goods. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, dried fish, and canned goods

loans.name: Winifreda

texts.en:
This is Winifreda, 63, resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is a widow and a mother to her children. Together with her children, Winifreda manages her household while operating her direct-selling business. She purchases clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics, and other products through popular brands such as Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina, and Shoe Exchange. She places orders with cash and then offers one-month-to-pay credits to her customers. Winifreda's prices are lower than those in the catalog and her profits come from investing her own income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 2,000 PHP in sales every week.

Winifreda is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to buy additional merchandise such as shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments, and other products to sell. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands and hopes to gain more customers. Winifreda hopes for good health for her and her loved ones. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her life and business and draw strength and inspiration from fellowship and studying the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments, and other products

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Eliza is 43 years old and married. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Eliza has a business buying and selling used clothing in the Philippines. Eliza requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional bundles of used clothing to sell.

Eliza has been in this business for three years. In the future, Eliza would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional bundles of used clothing to sell

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
This is Merlinda, She previously accessed a 30,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. She also has a food stall for additional income.

She would now like to apply for a 50,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to cover her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Adelaida is hoping to have business expansion and is dreaming of improving their living conditions. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store.

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
Epifania works hard to support her family. Epifania is married and has a business  buying and selling herbal medicines in the Philippines.

Epifania requested a PHP 20,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. to purchase more stock of herbal medicines to sell.

Epifania has been in this business for six years now.

In the future, Epifania would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of herbal medicines to sell

loans.name: Faitele

texts.en:
Faitele is 44 years old and married with four children. She owns and operates a business venture  painting different kinds of designs on clothes. She has three years of experience in this line of business. 

Rita needs a loan to buy materials, paints and painting brushes for her business. She hopes to use her profits to buy a printing machine for her business in the future. She joined SPBD in 2011.

loans.use: to buy materials, paints and  painting brushes

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima has operated a food vending business for the past years, cooking chapati (flat bread), rice and beans. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the requested loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour for her food vending business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the kind help.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour for her food vending business

loans.name: Mulheres Group

texts.en: Anastacia is one of the members from Mulheres Group. She is taking out a loan to add to her own working capital in order to buy some additional supplies such as fuel (diesel and petrol) and cooking seasonings, shampoo, coffee, etc. to sell. She is a hard-working woman. She started her business in 2010 with her own working capital of $70 dollars.

loans.use: to buy fuel (diesel and petrol), cooking  seasonings, shampoo, coffee, etc. for resale

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
This is Aileen, 42, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Teddy and mother to their children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Aileen operates a food processing business. She earns by selling her goods to her neighbors and to suppliers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional processed and frozen meat products to expand her product inventory. 

Aileen dreams that her business will continue grow and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional processed and frozen meat products needed in her business.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa opened a general store in 2010 with her own capital of 250 USD. She generates a good income from her store. Elsa lives in a town with her family. 

Elsa is requesting a 1,000 USD loan to buy stocks such as oil, slippers, detergent, and soap to keep at her store to sell. She is thinking of running a big business after years of involving herself in her store.

loans.use: to buy oil, slippers, detergent, and soap

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina is 32 years old and married with four children. She runs a small business selling cooked taro, banana, breadfruit and coconut cream with herring in her community and has been doing this for three years. 

Penina has requested a loan to buy more taro, banana, yams, herring and breadfruit. She joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital. With her earnings, Penina will help her family, pay for her children's education, and improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more taro, banana, yams, herring and breadfruit

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a farmer from the town of San Miguel, Bohol. Catherine is a married woman and has two young children. She has been engaged in rice farming for more than four years now. This is the source of her income. 

Catherine is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides. Through this, she will be able to improve her farm as well as her harvest. In the future, Catherine has hopes of making her business a success and sustainable. Moreover, Catherine wants to save money for the future schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia tiene 36 años de edad, vive en una casa alquilada junto a su esposo y sus 4 hijos .
Lucia es agricultora pero hace poco decidió comprar una incubadora y huevos para la crianza de pollos y de esa manera comenzar con un nuevo negocio. Fue lucia quien tomo la iniciativa de incorporarse en otro rubro, buscando mejores ingresos para su hogar y mejorar su calidad de vida, pero fue su esposo quien puso el capital para que compraran la incubadora y los huevos.Cuando llegaron a su actual localidad tuvieron muchos problemas económicos ya que lo habían invertido todo en la compra de terrenos pero gracias a la unión de toda su familia lograron salir adelante.Este es su primer crédito con Kiva, por lo que esta muy agradecida por el apoyo económico recibido el cual le ayudara a incrementar sus ingresos económicos.Con el monto solicitado de S/.1000 soles comprará huevos al por mayor para incubarlos y de esa manera aumentar su producción.
texts.en:
Lucia is 36 and lives in a rented home with her husband and four children.
She works in agriculture and decided to buy an incubator and eggs a short time ago to raise chickens and start a new business. Lucia has taken this initiative to enter a new field on her own; she is looking for a better income for her family and to improve her quality of life. However, her husband gave her the capital to buy the incubator and eggs.
When they started living in their current location, they had a lot of economic problems since they had invested everything in the purchase of land. However, thanks to the united effort of the whole family, they were able to get ahead. This is her first loan on Kiva, and she is very grateful for this economic support. It will help her to increase her income. With the requested 1000 soles, she will buy eggs wholesale to incubate and increase her production.

loans.use: to buy eggs wholesale.

loans.name: Reny

texts.en:
Reny is a former Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW for 10 years).   She is married to Walden and they are blessed with two children who are now in high school and elementary level of education.  Reny realized that living far from her family was hard so she decided to put up her 'sari-sari' store business as her source of income while her husband manages their farm and operates a 'tricycle' transportation business in their village.  

Aside from selling basic commodities, Reny wants to sell rice and hog feed.  With this in mind, she is requesting a loan of P20,000 as additional capital to buy said products.  She believes that by accessing the loan she will increase her sale and profit as well.

loans.use: to buy rice and hog feed to sell.

loans.name: Feviana

texts.en:
Feviana is 48 years old and married with four children. With three children currently in school, Feviana works very hard to provide for them.

Feviana runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell in her general store.

Feviana has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as shampoo, snack foods, cooking oil, soft drinks, etc. 

Feviana would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Faalafi

texts.en:
Faalafi is 70 years old and married with three children. She has pancake, ice cake, and handicraft businesses to earn a living and has been doing this for four years. 

Faalafi has requested a loan to buy a sack of sugar, flour, cooking oil, kava bowls, Samoan bangles, earrings, a cooler and pay school fees. She plans to use her profits to help her [grand]children's education and her family's living conditions. She joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy a sack of sugar, flour, cooking oil, kava bowls, Samoan bangles, earrings, a cooler and pay school fees

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea operates a business buying general merchandise from wholesalers to sell at a profit. She sells clothing for women and children and also has a food stall. Customers are attracted to Andrea's store due to her low prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members.  Andrea earns a minimum of 300 PHP every day.

Andrea is requesting a 17,000 PHP loan to buy additional stocks of kids and ladies wear along with other ready-to-wear products. She dreams that her business will continue to grow. Andrea meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy clothing and ready-to-wear products

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is a 44-year-old married woman with three children who lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. For the past five years, she has owned and managed a grocery store and she earns 20,000 PHP each month. Gina has been a member of GDMPC since 2010.

Gina is requesting a 25,000 PHP loan from GDMPC to purchase stocks of spices, noodles, sugar, and canned goods. She plans to develop her business for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase spices, noodles, sugar, and canned goods

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita is a married woman with one child. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Florita is 43 years old and has one child who is in school.

Florita has a general store business in the Philippines. Florita requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock like coffee, sugar, laundry soap, vinegar and other groceries to sell in her general store.

Florita has been in this business for three years. Florita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock like coffee, sugar, laundry soap, vinegar and other groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Dionesia

texts.en:
Dionesia is a 54-year-old married woman and a mother of eleven children from San Miguel, Bohol. Dionesia has been engaged in a rice farming business together with her husband for more than 20 years now. This is the source of their income.

Dionesia is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides. Through this, she will  be able to improve their farm and their harvest. In the future, Dionesia has hopes of expanding their farming business in order to generate more income.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Segundo William

texts.es:
Segundo es un hombre de 23 años, es soltero, vive en la ciudad de Chiclayo, en el distrito de Gaudalupe con sus padres y hermanos, el es una persona muy amable, trabajador y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo de superación; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tuvo de trabajar desde muy joven para ayudar a sus padres, Segundo no pudo estudiar la carrera profesional de Mecánica que deseaba, en sus ratos libres le gusta jugar futbol con sus amigos y en algunas ocasiones cocina un riquísimo Arroz con Pato para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Segundo trabaja como chofer de mototaxi, brindando servicios de transporte en su ciudad, adicionalmente los fines de semana trabaja como ayudante de manejo de maquinaria pesada, el trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por su responsabilidad y por el trato amable que brinda a los demás. 
Segundo se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la refacción y el mantenimiento general que necesita su mototaxi, de esta manera Segundo tendrá su herramienta de trabajo en mejores condiciones, así pues él seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Seguno is twenty-three years old, single, and lives in the city of Chiclayo, in the Guadalupe district, with his parents and brothers. He is very friendly, hard-working, and enthusiastic, and has a strong desire to succeed. Unfortunately, out of a necessity due to a lack of financial resources, he had to begin working very young to help his parents and couldn't study to become a professional mechanic as he wanted to.  In his free time, he likes to play soccer with his friends, and now and then he cooks a delicious dish of rice with duck to share with his family.

On his own initiative, and with a great deal of effort and dedication, Segundo works as an auto rickshaw driver, providing transportation services in his city. On the weekends, he also works as an assistant heavy machinery operator. He works about ten hours every day and believes that things are going well for him due to his responsibility and the friendly way he treats other people. 

Segundo is very grateful for his Kiva loans. Thanks to this help, he will be able to get the parts and maintenance that he needs for his auto rickshaw. With his work vehicle in better shape, Segundo will be able to keep working and pushing himself toward his big dream of owning his own home.

loans.use: pay for parts and general maintenance on his auto rickshaw.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora works hard to support her family. Leonora is married and has a business buying and selling plastic drums in the Philippines.

Leonora requested a PHP 19,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. to buy additional plastic drums to sell.

Leonora has been in this business for three years now.

Leonora would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional plastic drums to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To finish building a kitchen for their store

loans.name: Donisa

texts.en:
Donisa is a 29-year-old farmer from the town of Trinidad, Bohol. She is married and has two young children. Donisa has been engaged in a farming business together with her husband for more than twp years now. This is their main source of income.

Donisa is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides. With this, she will be able to grow healthy crops and harvest in abundance. In the future, Donisa has hopes of making her farming business a success and sustainable.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebbeca is 65 years old and married with eight children. She makes and sells fish and chips to earn a living and has been doing this for three years. 

Rebbeca has requested a loan to buy chips, fish, cooking oil and a pan for her business. She plans to use her profits to improve the business and also her family's living conditions. She joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy chips, fish, cooking oil and a pan

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en:
Phuong was born in 1973. She has a son who works and a daughter who attends secondary school. Her husband sells fish. His income is about 5,000,000 VND per month. Phuong has helped her husband sell fish and seafood at a market for ten years. Each month, she earns about 5,000,000 VND. The total income of her family is about 10,000,000 VND.
Phuong has taken part in the microfinance program from SEDA since 2005. The last cycle, she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow about 11,118,000 VND to sell more crabs and fish in her store. She always wants to enlarge her business in the market.

loans.use: to sell more crabs and fish in her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more palm fruits.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more fish so she can increase sales.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances Paulina did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Paulina sells cooked rice in Abrishia (near Cape Coast). She has been doing so for a number of years. As a single mother with two children, Paulina uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. Paulina will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of rice, which will aid her in improving her overall sales. Paulina wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all of her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase more rice.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is 59 years old, married and has only one child. They are currently residing in a rural community where planting and harvesting corn and raising livestock are the main sources of income.  Due to hardship of living, they are striving to generate income to satisfy their necessities and save some for future emergencies.  

Estrella aims to improve the business but she has limited capital. For this reason, she is asking for a loan of P15,000 to buy more stocks of fruit and vegetables to sell. Through hard work and strong determination, she believes that she will be able to make more improvements in the business.

loans.use: to buy more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
This is Lina, 50, a resident of Silang, Cavite Philippines. She is married to Ricardo and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to sustain their financial expenses.

Gloria operates a food vending business. Hers is a temporary food booth which takes its business to the customers. She goes to schools, offices, houses and streets  to sell her food. She earns a minimum of Php 300 a day. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting Php12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more types of food for her business.  

Gloria hopes to be successful both in life and in business. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for different ingredients and products for her food vending business.

loans.name: Lizelda

texts.en:
Lizelda works hard to support her family. Lizelda is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Lizelda requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like bread, shampoo, soft drinks, snack foods, etc. for her general store.

Lizelda has been in this business for three years now.

In the future, Lizelda would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like bread, shampoo, soft drinks, snack foods, etc. for her general store

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana is a farmer from the town of San Miguel, Bohol. She is a married woman and a mother of nine children. Feliciana has been engaged in the farming business for more than 10 years now.

Feliciana is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides and to pay for labor. With this loan, she will be able to improve her farm as well as their harvest.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides and to pay for labor

loans.name: Taesali

texts.en:
Taesali is a 48-year-old married woman with four children. She has a small plantation and grows taro, bananas and also yams to earn a living. She has been doing this for three years. 

Taesali has requested a loan to buy chemicals, a backpack sprayer, bushknives, a tree planter spade, rake, fertilizer, empty gallon jugs and a digging stick for her business. 

She has been a member of SPBD since 2011. With her profits, Taesali hopes to provide a better living for her family.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, a backpack sprayer, bushknives, a tree planter spade, rake, fertilizer, empty gallon jugs and a digging stick

loans.name: Isidra

texts.en:
Isidra is a farmer from the town of San Miguel, Bohol. She is married and has been engaged in the rice farming business for several years now. Her husband also works as a carpenter.

Isidra is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides. Through this loan, she will be able to improve her farm as well as her harvest. In the future, Isidra has hopes of expanding her business and making it a success.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
Nimfa is 39 years old and married with three children.

Nimfa works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell like rice, sugar, cooking oil, noodles, bread and other groceries in her general store.

Nimfa has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns additional income from fish vending.

Nimfa aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell like rice, sugar, cooking oil, noodles, bread and other groceries in her general store

loans.name: Rafaela

texts.en:
Rafaela is 63 years old and married with three children.

Rafaela works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her general store.

Rafaela has borrowed and paid 7 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 15 years and also earns additional income from pig fattening.

Rafaela aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Thang

texts.en:
Thang was born in 1977. She has two sons who attend primary school and secondary school. Her husband is a construction worker. His income is about 6,000,000 VND per month. Thang sells groceries to earn a living. Each month, she earns about 5,000,000 VND. She has done this job for 10 years. The total income of her family is about 10,000,000 VND.
Thang has taken part in SEDA’s microfinance program since 2004. The last cycle, she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow about 11,118,000 VND to buy more noodles, candy, beer, and biscuits for her grocery store. She always wants to enlarge her business in the market.

loans.use: to buy more noodles, candy, beer, and biscuits for her grocery store.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda is a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is 51 years old and she is happily married to Lorenzo, who works as a carpenter. God has blessed them with six loving children. Life indeed is hard, but by the grace of God they were able to raise their children well and they are helping each other in working for their family.

Belinda owns a variety store. This is a small store that can be owned by anyone in the community and the store is connected to or just inside their houses. This is where you can buy a sachet of shampoo or conditioner, a bar of soap, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil, an egg, and other things. She gets her product from a wholesaler at a lower price then she sells it per piece for a higher price to have profit. Her regular customers are her neighbors, passersby, and the people in the community. She earns 300 PHP a day.

To be able to expand her inventory, she is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. This loan will be a great help for her to add more products to her store.

Belinda hopes that her business will continue to grow and she is hoping to help her parents and give her children a good education and life. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, where she also draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa is a 53-year-old married woman and the mother of seven children. Josefa operates a sari-sari (variety) store business selling various goods and items to the people in her place. 

Josefa is asking for a loan to buy stock of items like canned goods, candies, noodles, and soap to sell. Through this she will be able to cater more buyers in her store, thus augmenting her sales and income.

loans.use: to buy stock of items like canned goods, candies, noodles, and soap to sell.

loans.name: Tien

texts.en:
Tien was born in 1965. She has two sons who are adults. Her husband is an irrigation worker. His income is about 7,000,000 VND per month. Tien raises chickens to earn a living. Each month, she earns about 2,000,000 VND. She has done this job for a long time. The total income of her family is about 9,000,000 VND.
Tien has taken part in SEDA’s microfinance program since 2005. The last cycle, she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow about 11,118,000 VND to buy food for chickens. She always wants to enlarge her farm of chickens.

loans.use: to buy food for chickens.

loans.name: La Fuente De Bendicion 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Reina is one of our businesswomen. She works selling seafood in her community, which is a rural area surrounded by forests and mountains. Reina started her business around six-and-a-half years ago with her personal savings. She sells all kinds of seafood such as squid, fish, crabs, and shrimp. Reina lives near Bahia, in the town of Hato Mayor, an agricultural zone. She has two children who still live at home, and she lives with her long-term partner, who is the children's father. Reina’s most important challenge is to live according to God’s will.

Reina is requesting her tenth loan from Esperanza International. Because her loan repayments have all been made punctually, she has been able to grow her business with the re-investment from each loan. She has had the opportunity to improve her life and family and expand her business to get more clients. Reina would like to save her profits to renovate her house and give her children a safer home. In the future, she wants to become a successful and professional businesswoman.

loans.use: to sell fish and seafood.

loans.name: Zoraida

texts.es: Zoraida de 51 años de edad,  habita en el municipio de Puerto Colombia, un lugar a la orilla del Mar Caribe, de gente con mucha calidez, sana y amante de las fiestas. Allí Zoraida  tiene un pequeño almacén, donde abundan las variedades,  que le gustan a los habitantes de esta población, como ropa, colonias, accesorios femeninos y para el hogar. Desde hace 5 años inició su negocio, pero ella tiene una experiencia comercial hace 20, cuando decidió generar sus propios ingresos desde su hogar. En su local vende directamente a los consumidores de sus productos al detalle y mediante las líneas de crédito y de contado. Su experiencia le ha indicado comprar los artículos que ofrecen en almacenes mayoristas de la ciudad de Barranquilla donde logra descuentos por compras en un mayor volumen. Hoy está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará ropa femenina e infantil, perfumería, cremas y accesorios varios, con esta inversión tendrá éxito porque conoce muy bien las oscilaciones de su mercado y especialmente donde comprar, para satisfacer a su distinguida clientela.  Mas adelante su meta es independizar su negocio de su hogar y terminar de remodelar su vivienda, su mayor desafío es lograr ahorros suficientes y un incremento importante en sus ventas que le permita aumentar su bienestar y el de su familia.
texts.en:
Zoraida, age 51, lives in the municipality of Puerto Colombia, on the shores of the Caribbean Sea. The people there are very warm, healthy, and love to celebrate. Zoraida has a small variety store there where she sells items that the locals like, such as clothing, cologne, women's accessories, and home accessories.
She started her business five years ago, but she has 20 years' experience as a merchant; she decided 20 years ago to start generating her own income from home. She sells her products directly to the customers on credit and for cash. Experience has taught her to buy the products that are offered by the wholesalers in the city of Barranquilla, where she can get discounts for purchases of higher volumes. She is now applying for a loan on Kiva, her first loan from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, with which she will buy women's and children's clothing, perfume, creams, and various accessories. She will have success with this investment because she knows the market fluctuations very well, and she especially knows where to buy to satisfy her distinguished clientele. For the future, her goal is to set up her business outside of her home and to finish remodeling her home. Her greatest challenge is saving up enough money, and increasing her income enough to support her and her family's well-being.

loans.use: to buy women's and children's clothing, perfume, creams, and varied accessories.

loans.name: Anali
